Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Flexible and Stretchable Electronic Skin Sensor
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project relates to the emerging "electronics skin" application. Adapting the technology towards early detection of pressure ulcers for at risk individuals with diabetes will result in prevention of amputations for persons with healed diabetic foot ulcers to less than 1%. In particular, a pressure ulcer is a skin injury resulting from prolonged pressure on the skin, often complicated by diabetic's common inability to feel pain due to nerve damage and blood circulation problems reducing the body's ability to heal and increasing risk of infection. Thus, early detection of pressure ulcers is important to prevent worsening conditions that necessitate amputation of limb(s). The technology from this project will result in a low-cost continuous monitoring system that is seamless to one's body and daily activities, enabling improved care for at risk individuals with diabetes.

This I-Corps project is based on the technology that combines electrically conductive nanomaterials with a flexible, rubber-like polymer platform in a novel design. The stretchable and flexible electrodes are composed of vertically aligned carbon nanotubes partially embedded in a polydimethylsiloxane substrate, which facilitates reliable and stable devices under both stretching and bending. As a proof-of-concept, the sensor was successfully tested for measuring biological signals of a person. This technology will directly impact the development of sensing and electronic storage devices toward medical and e-skin applications. In particular, the resulting endeavor will directly benefit the medical field, providing greater insight into prognosis and pattern recognition at critical wound development stages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the seven-week training program from the National I-Corps team at the New York City Regional Innovation Node, we received valuable training from the I-Corps teaching team and conducted over 100 customer discovery interviews. Through this training, we learned the principles and techniques of customer discovery, the business model canvas, and startup operation mechanics. At the beginning of the project, we hypothesized that the best commercial application would be to assist individuals suffering from diabetes to manage their illness and prevent the development of foot ulcers, which could lead to significant injury and ultimately to amputation. Though our initial interviews focused on diabetics and individuals engaged in assisting diabetics in managing their disease, we learned our initial hypothesis was not aligned with our proposed customer segments’ pains and gains. According to our interviews, while foot ulcers are a significant concern, they are generally manageable through therapies currently on the market, and our initial business model had little potential for commercialization. However, the fundamental technology and potential features of our system were still very promising towards wearable sensors and overall healthcare monitoring, as noted particularly by responses from medical professionals. Thus, we rejected our initial working hypothesis and explored other applications.

This exploration process ultimately led us to interview individuals in the prosthetics space, focusing on patients who had had lower limb amputations. Through the first-hand experience, we learned that this pivot (or pirouette) from an initial hypothesis to a new one based on the outcome of customer discovery interviews is a key stage in the I-Corps process. While directly probing those within the limb loss community ecosystem, we had learned that amputee patients are especially susceptible to developing injuries on their residual limbs. In addition, patients often have reduced sensation at the point where their residual limb contacts their prosthetics, causing complications with care management. Through the interview process, we ultimately learned an unmet customer need our technology may fulfill that that point of the interface can be a natural site to utilize a stretchable and flexible sensor that can seamlessly provide information on local biometrics, such as temperature and pressure, to alert the patient of a developing issue in real-time towards prevention of health complications resulting from festering wounds and further potential amputations.

Having identified an area of application with commercialization potential and impact, we undertook additional interviews to characterize the industry, market structure, and competition. Our findings based on our research and interviews led us to conclude a market opportunity for this technology associated with the prosthetics market. Some additional laboratory research into the sensor characteristics would be necessary to develop a product with a strong fit for the application.

In addition to providing new areas of focus for developing the stretchable and flexible skin sensor technology, a broader impact of this grant has been the promotion of I-Corps principles and opportunities within the university and the broader Stevens Institute of Technology entrepreneurial ecosystem. The team has used the training received through the I-Corps program to promote I-Corps and lean startup principles to other groups within Stevens, and especially within the Stevens Venture Center, which is Stevens incubator program for the launch of new ventures. Furthermore, based, in part, on this experience, Stevens has applied to be an affiliate member of the NYCRIN I-Corps Hub application that was submitted last year.

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2021
Modified by: Eui-Hyeok Yang
